title: Matthew Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:1, why should you not do your alms before men?
options: So your Father in heaven will reward you
Otherwise you have no reward of your Father which is in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Otherwise you have no reward of your Father which is in heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:1 warns that doing alms to be seen by men results in no reward from the Father in heaven.

questions.question: In Matthew 6:5, where do the hypocrites love to pray?
options: In the synagogues and in the corners of the streets
questions.correctAnswer: In the synagogues and in the corners of the streets
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:5 describes hypocrites praying publicly in synagogues and street corners to be seen of men.

questions.question: What does Matthew 6:6 instruct about prayer?
options: Pray in secret in your closet
Use many words to be heard
questions.correctAnswer: Pray in secret in your closet
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:6 teaches entering your closet to pray in secret to the Father who sees in secret.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:9, how should you address God in prayer?
options: Our Father which art in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Our Father which art in heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:9 begins the Lord's Prayer with addressing God as 'Our Father which art in heaven.'

questions.question: What is the first thing we are instructed to seek according to Matthew 6:33?
options: The kingdom of God and his righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom of God and his righteousness
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:33 instructs to seek first the kingdom of God and his righteousness before other things.

questions.question: What should you not lay up for yourselves, according to Matthew 6:19?
questions.correctAnswer: Treasures upon earth
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:19 warns against laying up treasures upon earth where moth and rust corrupt and thieves steal.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:20, where should you lay up treasures?
options: In heaven, where moth and rust do not corrupt
questions.correctAnswer: In heaven, where moth and rust do not corrupt
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:20 encourages laying up treasures in heaven, a place safe from decay and theft.

questions.question: In Matthew 6:24, it is said no man can serve two masters. Which two masters are mentioned?
questions.correctAnswer: God and mammon
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:24 explains that a person cannot serve both God and mammon (wealth).

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:26, who feeds the birds of the air?
questions.correctAnswer: Your heavenly Father
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:26 states that the heavenly Father feeds the birds, highlighting His care for creation.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Matthew 6:27 for not worrying about adding to your stature?
options: No one can add one cubit to his stature by worrying
questions.correctAnswer: No one can add one cubit to his stature by worrying
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:27 points out that worrying cannot add even a small measure to one's stature.

questions.question: Which verse instructs not to sound a trumpet before giving alms?
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 6:2
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:2 instructs not to sound a trumpet before giving alms as hypocrites do to be glorified by men.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 6:7 says we should use many words in prayer to be heard by God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:7 says not to use vain repetitions or many words like the heathen, as God already knows our needs.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 6:15 teaches that if you forgive others, your Father will forgive you.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:14-15 clearly state that forgiving others is linked to receiving forgiveness from your Father.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 6:34 tells us to take great thought for tomorrow because it will provide for itself.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:34 instructs not to worry about tomorrow as each day has enough trouble of its own.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'For where your ______ is, there will your heart be also.' (Matthew 6:21)
questions.correctAnswer: treasure
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:21 states that where your treasure is, there your heart will be also, showing the connection between what we value and our focus.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Matthew 6 teach us about the proper attitude in giving to others?
options: Give in secret without seeking human praise
Announce your giving loudly so others can admire you
Only give when others are watching
Give to receive immediate earthly rewards
questions.correctAnswer: Give in secret without seeking human praise
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:1-4 instructs believers to give alms in secret so that their Father in heaven will reward them openly, rather than seeking praise from men as the hypocrites do.

questions.question: What instruction does Jesus give about prayer in Matthew 6?
options: Pray privately in secret, not to be seen by others
Pray loudly in public places to show your devotion
Repeat long prayers to be heard by many
Use vain repetitions to impress others
questions.correctAnswer: Pray privately in secret, not to be seen by others
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:5-6 teaches that when praying, one should enter into their room, shut the door, and pray to the Father who is in secret, instead of praying publicly to be noticed by men.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6, why should we avoid 'vain repetitions' in prayer?
options: Because God already knows our needs before we ask
Because repetition makes prayers more powerful
Because other people like to hear long prayers
questions.correctAnswer: Because God already knows our needs before we ask
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:7-8 explains that vain repetitions are unnecessary as God knows what we have need of before we ask Him.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of the Lord’s Prayer in Matthew 6:9-13?
options: Honoring God’s name and seeking His kingdom and will
Asking for wealth and material blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Honoring God’s name and seeking His kingdom and will
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:9-10 highlights the importance of honoring God's name, asking for His kingdom to come, and His will to be done on earth as in heaven.

questions.question: What does Matthew 6 say about forgiveness and its effect on our relationship with God?
options: If we forgive others, God will forgive us; if not, He will not forgive us
God forgives us regardless of our actions
We should forgive only when asked
questions.correctAnswer: If we forgive others, God will forgive us; if not, He will not forgive us
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:14-15 teaches that forgiving others is essential because God will forgive us only if we forgive others their trespasses.

questions.question: How should believers conduct themselves when fasting according to Matthew 6?
options: Fast discreetly without showing sadness to gain God’s reward
Display sadness and disfigure face to show piety
questions.correctAnswer: Fast discreetly without showing sadness to gain God’s reward
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:16-18 instructs believers to fast without outward signs of sadness or showiness, but to anoint the head and wash the face so that fasting is done in secret and God rewards openly.

questions.question: What does Matthew 6 teach about where believers should store their treasures?
options: In heaven, where they are safe from decay and theft
On earth, where they can be easily accessed
questions.correctAnswer: In heaven, where they are safe from decay and theft
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:19-20 advises believers to store treasures in heaven, not on earth, because earthly treasures can decay and be stolen, but heavenly treasures are eternal.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6, what determines the focus of your heart?
options: Where your treasure is laid up
The amount of prayer you say
questions.correctAnswer: Where your treasure is laid up
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:21 states that where your treasure is, there your heart will be also, indicating the connection between what we value and our inner focus.

questions.question: How does Matthew 6 describe the effect of having a 'single' eye?
options: Your whole body will be full of light
You will be admired by others
You will be free from temptation
questions.correctAnswer: Your whole body will be full of light
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:22 explains that the eye is the light of the body, and if your eye is single (focused on God), your whole body will be full of light.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give about serving two masters in Matthew 6?
options: You cannot serve both God and mammon (wealth)
You can serve both God and money equally
It is best to serve only yourself
Serve those who give you the most
questions.correctAnswer: You cannot serve both God and mammon (wealth)
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:24 teaches that no one can serve two masters because they will hate one and love the other; specifically, you cannot serve God and money.

questions.question: Based on Matthew 6, what attitude should believers have towards worry about daily needs?
options: Trust God to provide and do not be anxious about food, drink, or clothing
Worry constantly to ensure needs are met
Rely only on personal effort without trusting God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to provide and do not be anxious about food, drink, or clothing
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:25-34 teaches believers not to worry about their daily needs because God knows their needs and will provide, so they should seek His kingdom first.

questions.question: What example does Jesus use in Matthew 6 to show God’s provision for His creation?
options: The birds of the air and the lilies of the field
questions.correctAnswer: The birds of the air and the lilies of the field
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:26, 28-29 uses birds who do not sow or reap and lilies that grow without toil as examples of God's care and provision.

questions.question: How does Matthew 6 encourage believers to prioritize their lives?
options: Seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:33 commands believers to prioritize seeking God's kingdom and righteousness, promising all other needs will be added.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 6, fasting should be done to gain admiration from others.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:16-18 teaches that fasting should be done in secret and not for human admiration, as those who fast to be seen have already received their reward.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 6 teaches that worry can add a single cubit to your stature.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:27 states that no one can add a single cubit to their stature by worrying, emphasizing the futility of anxiety.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Matthew 6, what does Jesus instruct about giving alms so that it is not hypocritical?
options: Do not sound a trumpet before giving
Give only to those who can repay you
questions.correctAnswer: Do not sound a trumpet before giving
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:2 warns against sounding a trumpet before giving alms as the hypocrites do, to gain human glory, indicating true giving should be discreet.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'thy left hand know not what thy right hand doeth' in Matthew 6:3?
options: It symbolizes secrecy and humility in giving
It refers to a ritual cleansing practice
It means to give only with the right hand
It encourages public declaration of generosity
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes secrecy and humility in giving
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:3 uses this phrase to emphasize that almsgiving should be done secretly and without seeking attention, reflecting humility.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6, where should one pray to avoid hypocrisy?
options: In a private room with the door shut
questions.correctAnswer: In a private room with the door shut
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:6 instructs believers to pray in secret, entering their closet and shutting the door, so God who sees in secret rewards openly.

questions.question: What is the primary criticism Jesus makes about the prayers of the 'heathen' in Matthew 6:7?
options: Using vain repetitions thinking it will make them heard
Praying in a language not understood
questions.correctAnswer: Using vain repetitions thinking it will make them heard
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:7 criticizes repetitive, empty phrases in prayer, highlighting that God knows our needs before we ask.

questions.question: The Lord's Prayer in Matthew 6:9-13 contains a petition for 'Thy kingdom come.' How does this reflect Old Testament messianic expectations?
options: It anticipates God's rule and restoration as prophesied in Isaiah
It refers to a literal kingdom on earth established by David
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates God's rule and restoration as prophesied in Isaiah
questions.explanation: The prayer aligns with Isaiah’s prophecies of God’s coming kingdom (Isaiah 9:6-7) emphasizing divine reign and righteousness.

questions.question: In Matthew 6:12, what is the relationship between forgiving others and receiving forgiveness from God?
options: Forgiving others is a prerequisite for God’s forgiveness
Forgiveness is unrelated to God’s mercy
God forgives regardless of our forgiveness to others
questions.correctAnswer: Forgiving others is a prerequisite for God’s forgiveness
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:14-15 teach that God forgives those who forgive others, showing a reciprocal ethical principle.

questions.question: How does Jesus instruct believers to conduct fasting according to Matthew 6?
options: Fast without showing outward signs of sadness or disfigurement
Announce the fast to the community
questions.correctAnswer: Fast without showing outward signs of sadness or disfigurement
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:16-18 advises fasting in secret without outward show, contrasting with hypocrites who disfigure faces to appear fasting.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by 'lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven' in Matthew 6:20?
options: Invest in eternal, incorruptible rewards rather than earthly wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Invest in eternal, incorruptible rewards rather than earthly wealth
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:19-20 contrasts perishable earthly treasures with imperishable heavenly ones, emphasizing eternal priorities.

questions.question: In the metaphor of the eye as the lamp of the body (Matthew 6:22-23), what does a 'single' or 'healthy' eye symbolize?
options: A focused and pure spiritual vision
questions.correctAnswer: A focused and pure spiritual vision
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:22 describes a 'single' eye as the body being full of light, symbolizing clear, righteous spiritual perception.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:24, why is it impossible to serve two masters?
options: Because one will be loved and the other hated
Because both masters demand identical things
Because one master is always evil
questions.correctAnswer: Because one will be loved and the other hated
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:24 explains the incompatibility of serving God and mammon due to conflicting loyalties and affections.

questions.question: How does the instruction in Matthew 6:25-34 about not worrying connect to Old Testament trust themes?
options: It echoes Psalm 37 and Proverbs emphasizing trust in God’s provision
It contradicts Old Testament laws about self-reliance
It introduces a new concept absent in earlier scripture
It recommends storing food for famine
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes Psalm 37 and Proverbs emphasizing trust in God’s provision
questions.explanation: The teaching on trusting God’s provision in Matthew 6 parallels wisdom literature like Psalm 37:25 and Proverbs 3:5-6.

questions.question: What rhetorical device is present in Matthew 6:27 where Jesus asks, 'Which of you by taking thought can add one cubit unto his stature?'
options: Rhetorical question to emphasize human limitation
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical question to emphasize human limitation
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:27 uses a rhetorical question highlighting that worry cannot control life’s outcomes, emphasizing dependence on God.

questions.question: What cultural practice of the Pharisees and hypocrites is Jesus critiquing in Matthew 6:16?
options: Making their fasting visible by sad faces
questions.correctAnswer: Making their fasting visible by sad faces
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:16 critiques hypocrites disfiguring faces to show off their fasting publicly for human praise.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 6:8, God does not know our needs until we ask Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:8 clearly states that God knows our needs before we ask, emphasizing His omniscience.

questions.question: What theme does the refrain 'your Father which seeth in secret shall reward you openly' emphasize throughout Matthew 6?
options: God’s recognition of sincere, private devotion
The need for public religious display
questions.correctAnswer: God’s recognition of sincere, private devotion
questions.explanation: Verses such as Matthew 6:4, 6, and 18 emphasize that God rewards secret, sincere acts rather than public show.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:1-4, what is the proper motivation for giving alms?
options: To please the Father who sees in secret
questions.correctAnswer: To please the Father who sees in secret
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:1-4 teaches that almsgiving should be done in secret to please God who sees in secret, not for human recognition. This aligns with Proverbs 21:14, Hebrews 13:16, Luke 21:1-4, and Acts 20:35, emphasizing the heart's motive before God.

questions.question: What does Jesus instruct about prayer in Matthew 6:5-6?
options: Pray loudly in public to be heard
Pray privately to the Father who sees in secret
questions.correctAnswer: Pray privately to the Father who sees in secret
questions.explanation: Jesus commands prayer in secret, contrasting the hypocrites who pray publicly for show (Matthew 6:5-6). This reflects Psalm 51:6, Jeremiah 23:24, 1 Kings 8:39, and Isaiah 26:20 on God's omnipresence and the sincerity of secret prayer.

questions.question: What is warned against in prayer according to Matthew 6:7-8?
questions.correctAnswer: Using vain repetitions
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:7-8 warns against vain repetitions, often linked to empty ritualistic speech, because God knows our needs before we ask. This aligns with Isaiah 29:13, Ecclesiastes 5:2, 1 Samuel 15:22, and Hosea 6:6 emphasizing sincere worship over empty words.

questions.question: How does the Lord's Prayer in Matthew 6:9-13 reflect God's attributes?
options: God is Father, holy, sovereign, provider, forgiving, and protector
God is indifferent to human needs
questions.correctAnswer: God is Father, holy, sovereign, provider, forgiving, and protector
questions.explanation: The Lord's Prayer acknowledges God as Father (Matthew 6:9), holy (6:9), sovereign (6:10), provider (6:11), forgiving (6:12), and protector (6:13). This corresponds with Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 103:13, Isaiah 6:3, Philippians 4:19, 1 John 1:9, and Psalm 91:1-2.

questions.question: According to Matthew 6:14-15, what is the relationship between forgiving others and receiving forgiveness from God?
options: Forgiving others is unrelated to divine forgiveness
God forgives regardless of our forgiveness
Forgiving others is necessary to receive forgiveness from God
Only God forgives, humans need not forgive
questions.correctAnswer: Forgiving others is necessary to receive forgiveness from God
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:14-15 teaches that forgiving others is a condition for receiving God's forgiveness, reflecting the principle of reciprocal mercy seen in Luke 6:37, Mark 11:25, Ephesians 4:32, and Colossians 3:13.

questions.question: What attitude does Jesus prescribe for fasting in Matthew 6:16-18?
options: To fast publicly and show sorrowful faces
To fast with joy and in secret
questions.correctAnswer: To fast with joy and in secret
questions.explanation: Jesus instructs fasting without outward display or sadness, but in secret with a joyful demeanor (Matthew 6:16-18). This matches Isaiah 58:5-7, Joel 2:12, Zechariah 7:5, and Psalm 35:13 emphasizing sincere fasting that pleases God.

questions.question: What does Jesus warn against laying up in Matthew 6:19-21?
questions.correctAnswer: Treasures on earth
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:19-21 warns against storing treasures on earth where they can decay or be stolen, urging believers to invest in heavenly treasures. This is consistent with Proverbs 23:4-5, Luke 12:33-34, Colossians 3:2, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What does the 'single eye' metaphor in Matthew 6:22-23 signify?
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual focus and purity
questions.explanation: The 'single eye' symbolizes a focused and pure spiritual vision that fills the whole body with light (Matthew 6:22-23). This parallels Psalm 119:105, Ephesians 1:18, Proverbs 4:25-27, and 2 Corinthians 4:6 regarding enlightenment by God's truth.

questions.question: What does Matthew 6:24 say about serving two masters?
options: A person can serve God and money equally
You cannot serve God and mammon
Serving God does not require exclusivity
questions.correctAnswer: You cannot serve God and mammon
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:24 teaches exclusive allegiance to God, rejecting divided loyalty with wealth (mammon). This is echoed in Deuteronomy 6:5, Joshua 24:15, 1 Kings 18:21, and James 4:4 emphasizing wholehearted devotion to God.

questions.question: How does Jesus address anxiety about daily needs in Matthew 6:25-34?
options: God does not care about daily needs
Trust God to provide and seek His kingdom first
Work hard without relying on God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to provide and seek His kingdom first
questions.explanation: Jesus commands trust in God's provision and prioritizing God's kingdom (Matthew 6:25-34), consistent with Psalm 37:25, Philippians 4:6-7, Isaiah 41:10, and 1 Peter 5:7, which encourage reliance on God over worry.

questions.question: What does Jesus illustrate about God's provision using the birds of the air in Matthew 6:26?
options: Birds work hard to store food
Birds are fed by God despite no farming
questions.correctAnswer: Birds are fed by God despite no farming
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:26 shows that God feeds birds who neither sow nor reap, highlighting His care. This mirrors Psalm 147:9, Job 38:41, Luke 12:24, and Jeremiah 29:11 on God's providential care for creation.

questions.question: What is the significance of seeking first the kingdom of God in Matthew 6:33?
options: It leads to spiritual and material provision
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to spiritual and material provision
questions.explanation: Seeking God's kingdom first results in God providing all needs (Matthew 6:33). This is supported by Psalm 34:10, Proverbs 3:5-6, Isaiah 55:6-7, and Hebrews 11:6 emphasizing trust and obedience bringing God's blessing.

questions.question: How does Matthew 6:27 challenge human control over life?
options: Humans can extend life by worrying
Worrying adds no value to life
Physical stature can be increased by thought
questions.correctAnswer: Worrying adds no value to life
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:27 states that worry cannot add even a cubit to life, teaching the futility of anxiety. This relates to Ecclesiastes 1:14, Job 1:21-22, Psalm 39:4-5, and Philippians 4:6 about life's brevity and God's sovereignty.

questions.question: Why does Jesus compare the lilies of the field to Solomon's glory in Matthew 6:28-29?
options: To show natural beauty exceeds human splendor
questions.correctAnswer: To show natural beauty exceeds human splendor
questions.explanation: Jesus highlights that lilies, clothed by God, surpass Solomon's glory (Matthew 6:28-29), illustrating God's generous provision. This is consistent with Job 40:10-14, Psalm 104:24, Isaiah 40:8, and Ecclesiastes 3:11 about God's creative power and care.

questions.question: What does Matthew 6:30 teach about faith in God's care?
options: God will clothe His people if they trust Him
questions.correctAnswer: God will clothe His people if they trust Him
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:30 challenges little faith, affirming that God will provide clothing as He does the grass, underscoring trust in divine care. This aligns with Psalm 34:7, Isaiah 41:10, Hebrews 12:2, and 2 Corinthians 12:9 emphasizing reliance on God.
